useful.title: Useful Information about Gas Piston Units

whatIsGPU.title: What is a Gas-Piston Unit? Operating Principle

definition.title: What is a Gas-Piston Unit?
definition.description: A gas-piston power plant is an autonomous unit that produces electricity and heat by burning gas in an internal combustion engine. It can use natural gas, biogas, mine gas, or synthetic gas.

structure.title: Design and Systems
structure.typesIntro: Gas-piston units come in different configurations:
structure.type1: Open design (all components on a frame)
structure.type2: Enclosed (in a container or sound-insulated housing)

step1.title: üîπ 1. Gas Supply to the Engine and Combustion Process
step1.description: üî∏ Gas (natural, biogas, etc.) is supplied from the gas pipeline through:
step1.point5: The mixture then enters the cylinders of the internal combustion engine
step1.point6: Ignition of the mixture creates pressure on the pistons

step2.title: üîπ 2. Crankshaft Rotation
step2.description: Pistons transfer force to the crankshaft, which:
step2.point1: Converts linear motion into rotational motion
step2.point2: Rotates the flywheel and clutch connected to the generator

step3.title: üîπ 3. Electricity Generation
step3.point2: Generates electricity based on electromagnetic induction
step3.point3: The signal is sent to the automation system which manages current distribution, parallel operation with the grid, and overload protection

step4.title: üîπ 4. Heat Recovery from the Engine through Heat Exchangers
step4.description: During combustion, a large amount of heat is released:
step4.point2: üî• From the oil (through an oil heat exchanger)

step5.title: üîπ 5. Using Heat for Heating or Hot Water Supply
step5.description: Heated water or steam is transferred to:
step5.point2: üíß Hot water supply (showers, restrooms, technological needs)
step5.point3: If there is excess heat ‚Äî it's diverted to a cooling tower or dry cooler

step6.title: üîπ 6. Trigeneration: Producing Cold from Heat
step6.description: Part of the thermal energy is supplied to:
step6.point2: Hot water or steam acts as an energy source in this process
step6.point4: Chilled water is supplied to the air conditioning system or for technological equipment cooling

indicators.title: Technical and Economic Indicators
indicators.point3: Share of recovered heat ‚Äî up to 45%
indicators.point4: Savings compared to separate production ‚Äî up to 50%
indicators.point5: Reduction of energy losses ‚Äî up to 60%

cogeneration.title: Cogeneration = Electricity + Heat
cogeneration.formula: Formula: Œ∑ total = Œ∑ electrical + Œ∑ thermal ‚âà 45% + 45% = up to 90%

trigeneration.title: Trigeneration = Electricity + Heat + Cold
trigeneration.description: An absorption refrigeration machine (ABHM) converts heat into cold. Instead of electricity, hot water or steam is used as the energy source.
trigeneration.example1: 1 MW of hot water ‚Üí up to 800 kW of cooling capacity
trigeneration.example2: 1 MW of steam ‚Üí up to 1400 kW of cooling capacity

howToChooseGPU.title: How to Choose the Right Gas-Piston Unit (GPU)
howToChooseGPU.intro1: Gas-piston units (GPUs) are an effective solution for autonomous power supply, reducing electricity costs, and increasing business energy independence.
howToChooseGPU.intro2: However, to choose the optimal GPU, it's important to consider many technical parameters and characteristics of the facility where it will be installed. In this article, we'll discuss what to pay attention to when choosing a gas-piston unit to achieve maximum efficiency and reliability.

parameter1.title: 1. Determining Power Capacity and Operating Mode
parameter1.description: Before purchasing a GPU, it's necessary to accurately calculate the power consumption of the facility and choose a unit with appropriate characteristics.
parameter1.point1: What are the peak and average daily loads at the facility?
parameter1.point2: Will the GPU be used as the primary or backup power source?
parameter1.point3: Is it necessary to consider the possibility of parallel operation of several units?
parameter1.tip: If the unit will be used as the main power source, choose a GPU with a power reserve of 10-15% to account for load variations. If the GPU will work in parallel with the grid or as a backup, you can calculate the capacity more precisely based on critical loads.

parameter2.title: 2. Fuel Efficiency and Gas Consumption
parameter2.description: The efficiency of a GPU is measured in electrical efficiency, thermal efficiency, and total efficiency (cogeneration). The higher the efficiency, the lower the operating costs.
parameter2.point1: Electrical efficiency (%) ‚Äì shows how much energy from gas is converted into electricity. In good models, this indicator is 38-46%.
parameter2.point2: Thermal efficiency (%) ‚Äì if heat utilization is planned, it's important to consider thermal efficiency (usually 40-48%).
parameter2.point3: Total efficiency (%) ‚Äì in combined production of electricity and heat (cogeneration), efficiency can reach 90% or higher.
parameter2.point4: Gas consumption ‚Äì measured in m¬≥/MW el and affects the cost of electricity production.
parameter2.tip: Choose a unit with maximum total efficiency (for example, Jenbacher, MWM, Bergen, W√§rtsil√§) for cogeneration solutions. If heat is not utilized, you should focus on electrical efficiency.

parameter3.title: 3. Gas Supply and Pressure at the Facility
parameter3.description: One of the most important factors is the ability to supply the necessary amount of gas with the required pressure parameters.
parameter3.point1: Is there a connection to the gas network?
parameter3.point2: Is the gas pressure sufficient? (usually from 100 mbar to 5 bar is required, depending on the model)
parameter3.point3: Is the gas supply stable? (important for uninterrupted operation)
parameter3.point4: Possibility of installing a gas pressure regulator to bring gas parameters to the required standard.
parameter3.tip: If the gas pressure at the facility is unstable, installation of a pressure regulator or compressor station is required, which will increase the initial costs.

parameter4.title: 4. Reliability, Service Life, and Maintenance Frequency
parameter4.description: Different manufacturers offer GPUs with varying engine life and maintenance intervals.
parameter4.point1: Service life until major overhaul ‚Äì top brands (Jenbacher, MWM, Bergen, W√§rtsil√§) offer 70,000 ‚Äì 100,000 hours.
parameter4.point2: Maintenance frequency ‚Äì affects maintenance costs (Jenbacher, W√§rtsil√§ require maintenance every 1,500 - 2,000 hours, while CAT, Cummins ‚Äì 3,000 - 4,000 hours).
parameter4.point3: Availability of spare parts and service support ‚Äì European brands may require complex maintenance, while American and Asian brands are more accessible in this regard.

parameter5.title: 5. Operating Conditions and Site Characteristics
parameter5.description: Before installing a GPU, it's important to consider the conditions at the site.
parameter5.point1: Fuel availability ‚Äì is there a stable supply of natural gas with the required pressure?
parameter5.point2: Temperature conditions ‚Äì in low temperatures, a heating system should be considered.
parameter5.point3: Noise restrictions ‚Äì if the GPU is located near residential buildings, sound insulation is important.
parameter5.point4: Dimensions and weight ‚Äì is there enough space at the facility for installing and servicing the unit?
parameter5.point5: Emission restrictions ‚Äì do NOx, CO, and CO‚ÇÇ emissions comply with environmental standards?
parameter5.tip: Before purchasing, conduct a site audit ‚Äì this will help choose the right unit option and minimize costs for site preparation.

parameter6.title: 6. Importance of Transformer and Power Coordination
parameter6.description: When connecting a GPU to the power grid, it's important to consider the availability of a transformer and the permitted power capacity at the facility.
parameter6.point1: Permitted power capacity of the facility ‚Äì can the GPU be connected to the existing power system?
parameter6.point2: Availability of a transformer ‚Äì if the GPU generates 400V, and the grid accepts 6-10 kV, a transformer will be required.
parameter6.point3: Type of grid connection ‚Äì will the facility consume all electricity itself or sell part of it to the grid?
parameter6.point4: Documents for electricity sales ‚Äì permission for parallel operation with the grid is required.
parameter6.tip: If electricity sales to the grid are planned, it's important to coordinate power limits with the grid operator in advance, and install an automatic generation regulation system (AGR).

parameter7.title: 7. Choosing the Type of Gas-Piston Unit (GPU or CHP)
parameter7.description: There are different types of gas-piston units depending on the energy produced.
parameter7.point2: CHP (cogeneration units) ‚Äì produce both electricity and heat.
parameter7.point3: Trigeneration ‚Äì produce electricity, heat, and cooling.
parameter7.tip: If you have a need for heat (for example, building heating, technological processes), choose CHP ‚Äì this will reduce the cost of energy.

parameter8.title: 8. Budget and Payback Calculation
parameter8.description: The cost of a GPU varies from $100,000 to several million dollars, so it's important to consider not only the purchase price but also operating costs.
parameter8.tip: Use a payback calculator to compare the cost of purchasing electricity from the grid and producing it with a GPU. For example, with a gas price of 18.5 UAH/m¬≥ and grid electricity at 9 UAH/kWh, you can save up to 50% on electricity.

parameter9.title: 9. Service Support and Warranty
parameter9.description: When choosing a GPU, it's important to understand what service offerings the manufacturer or its official representatives provide.
parameter9.point1: Availability of service centers in the region ‚Äì affects the efficiency of maintenance.
parameter9.point2: Manufacturer's warranty ‚Äì usually from 1 to 5 years, but it's better to choose models with the possibility of warranty extension.
parameter9.point3: Availability of remote monitoring system ‚Äì allows remote management and diagnostics of the unit.
parameter9.tip: Choose a GPU with a long-term warranty and remote monitoring capability to reduce maintenance costs.

summary.title: Summary: How to Choose the Optimal Gas-Piston Unit?
summary.point1: Calculate the required power and determine the operating mode (primary/backup).
summary.point2: Evaluate the operating conditions and characteristics of the site for GPU placement: availability of electrical and gas infrastructure for connection, as well as the necessary space.
summary.point3: Compare efficiency and fuel consumption of different models.
summary.point4: Consider service life and maintenance intervals.
summary.point5: Determine the budget and calculate payback.
summary.point6: Check the availability of service support in your region.
summary.point7: Choose between GPU or CHP if cogeneration is required.
summary.conclusion: The right choice of a gas-piston unit will provide reliable power supply, minimize fuel and maintenance costs, and accelerate investment payback.

serviceLife.title: Service Life of Generators by Brand, Maintenance Intervals, and Types

serviceInterval.title: Main Types of Gas Piston Unit Maintenance:

regular.title: Regular Maintenance
regular.desc: ‚Äì performed every 1,500‚Äì3,000 operating hours. Includes oil, filter, and spark plug replacement, as well as diagnostics of the main equipment components.

middle.title: Midlife Overhaul
middle.desc: ‚Äì carried out after 25,000‚Äì30,000 operating hours. Involves a more thorough inspection and replacement of worn engine components.

major.title: Major Overhaul
major.desc: ‚Äì conducted after 55,000‚Äì60,000 operating hours. Includes complete engine disassembly, replacement of major components, and restoration of the unit's resources to the level of a new one.

maintenanceTypes.sparkPlugsChange: Replacement (often at every maintenance or every other service)
maintenanceTypes.oilAnalysisCheck: Checking for metal particles and wear indicators
maintenanceTypes.coolantCheck: Level check, top-up or replacement if needed
maintenanceTypes.generatorCheck: Insulation check, load testing, brush inspection (if applicable)
maintenanceTypes.automationCheck: Testing, log updates, control system communication check
maintenanceTypes.midLifeDescription: Purpose: extend engine life until major overhaul, address wear of critical components. Usually performed on-site, duration ‚Äî 3‚Äì10 days.

midLife.point1: Replacement of pistons or piston rings
midLife.point3: Replacement or overhaul of cylinder heads
midLife.point4: Cleaning and inspection of the turbocharger
midLife.point5: Inspection and replacement of injectors, spark plugs, fuel system components
midLife.point7: Inspection of oil system, cooling system, gas valves

maintenanceTypes.majorDescription: Purpose: complete engine rebuild extending service life by another 60,000 hours. Often conducted at specialized facilities or manufacturer plants, duration ‚Äî 2‚Äì4 weeks.

major.point4: Complete cylinder set replacement (liners, pistons, connecting rods)
major.point5: Repair/replacement of turbocharger, pumps, radiators, thermostats
major.point6: Updating gas, oil, and cooling systems

brands.title: Popular manufacturers
brands.jenbacher: Austrian manufacturer, a market leader. Jenbacher is renowned for high reliability and adaptability to various gas types (natural gas, biogas, landfill gas, mine gas, and even hydrogen blends). The units offer one of the highest efficiencies on the market ‚Äì up to 90% in cogeneration, making them an excellent choice for industry and utilities. However, the high equipment cost requires careful payback calculation.
brands.mwm: German brand with a 150-year history. MWM offers units with optimized fuel consumption, reducing operating costs. High automation and remote monitoring. Premium segment with a high price.
brands.mtu: German manufacturer of premium solutions (Rolls-Royce). Modular units for hybrid systems. Ideal for facilities with high reliability demands. Downsides ‚Äì frequent maintenance and expensive parts.
brands.cat: American industrial giant. CAT GPU advantages include a wide service network, parts availability, and high power. However, efficiency and performance lag behind European counterparts, with above-average fuel consumption.
brands.bergen: Norwegian brand of large units. Known for enhanced reliability and long engine life (up to 100,000 hours). Downsides: high cost and complex service.
brands.wartsila: Finnish manufacturer for large-scale generation. Flexible with various fuel types. High efficiency and durability. Downsides: high price and service complexity.
brands.cummins: American manufacturer of affordable and reliable GPUs. Simple design and parts availability. Lags behind European brands in efficiency and service life, with higher fuel consumption.
brands.doosan: South Korean corporation, popular in Asia and Eastern Europe. Affordable price and good performance. Shorter service life until overhaul and lower efficiency than premium brands.
brands.himoinsa: Spanish brand of compact and mobile GPUs. Suitable for small facilities and backup power. Relatively short service life and lower efficiency.
brands.gentec: Manufacturer of mid-range GPUs with flexible customization. Service support is limited compared to major brands.
brands.mitsubishi: Japanese manufacturer with innovative solutions. Enhanced reliability, long service life, and efficiency. Downsides: high cost and service complexity.

programs.title: Distributed generation strategy in Ukraine
programs.paragraph1: Ukraine is rapidly developing a distributed generation program, which involves installing independent energy sources directly at enterprises and communities. Gas piston units (GPUs) play a key role as an efficient and reliable solution for producing electricity and heat.
programs.paragraph2: GPUs reduce reliance on centralized grids, cut energy costs, and ensure energy independence during peak loads or crises. The government supports this direction through regulatory mechanisms and incentives for businesses to adopt local generation sources, especially relevant amid energy system instability.
programs.psoDescription: Currently, Resolution No. 222 of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine (PSO agreement) applies to electricity producers using gas piston units:
programs.psoPoint1: * under the PSO agreement for electricity producers on GPUs ‚Äì price of 14 UAH per 1 m¬≥ until 31.10.2025
programs.psoPoint2: * under the PSO agreement for electricity and heat producers on GPUs ‚Äì price of 18 UAH per 1 m¬≥ until 31.10.2025
programs.loansDescription: Preferential loan rates of 5-7-9% per annum, approved by the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine, are currently available for purchasing energy equipment (including gas piston units):
programs.link1: Ministry of Energy: Development of distributed generation
programs.link4: Documentation and specifics of GPU and CHP connection

intro.p1: If you‚Äôve decided to switch to self-generation, become energy-independent, and significantly cut costs ‚Äì we‚Äôre ready to be your partner on this journey.
intro.p2: Gen Expert offers not only equipment selection and supply but also project support, implementation assistance, and the possibility of co-financing.
intro.p3: We‚Äôre open to partnership, where our expertise, equipment, and market knowledge complement your initiative and readiness to implement effective solutions.

electrical.title: Electrical infrastructure:
electrical.point3: Electrical power for the facility‚Äôs own needs, kW;

gas.point4: Maximum possible gas order volume at the connection point, m¬≥/h.

heat.title: Heat demand:
heat.point1: Heat consumption schedule by month for the last year and the last 3 months, kW;
